She is distressed at being separated from her Husband and at having to appear before the Magistrate, but born up with the conviction that she has done a meritorious thing! and the best thing for her children.

5 There are certain persons whose characteristic it is to be always mal a propos [inopportune]. Poor Mrs George Welsh is one. I had set myself seriously to getting ready a cap or two for the Grange (everything is for the Grange just now) when in walked that illtimed woman and kept me idle till it was time to keep an appointment with Miss Farrer. The evening was the fastest I have had for some time. Geraldine and I started at half after four to drink tea at Miss Anderton’s, and go after to Drury Lane Theater;The Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. and Edward Sterling who happened to call drove us there in his cab. The first part of the lark if not the whole of it was overshadowed by an imagination (only an imagination it proved) that I had left the sideboard locked, and so Mr C would have to go without wine for his pudding! Miss Farrer joined us at Miss Andertons and then we all walked to the Theater. We had the best box in the house. And Charles Mathews played in ‘Used Up’—Charles J. Mathews (1803–78; ODNB), m. to Lucia Elizabetta, b. Bartolozzi, (Madame Vestris) (1797–1856); acting manager of the Theatre Royal. Used Up was adapted by Mathews and D. L. Bourcicault from F. A. Duvert and A. T. de Lauzanne de Vauxrousse, L’homme blasé (1848?). Then we had a “Lady” kissing Lions and a big black Bear, the latter eating sugar out of her mouth! If one day it don’t eat her! Then the horrid Egyptian Piece in which poor Miss Anderton has to play a Nubian Boy!Used Up was followed by Miss Labarrère’s Troupe of Wild Animals, and Nitocris, by Edward Fitzball (17921793–1873; ODNB), in which Anderton played the part of a young Egyptian nobleman, Koephed. Edward came from a party to our box; And Miss Anderton, when her part was over, came. It was one in the morning when Edward left me at my own door. Miss Anderton is getting to have a
swollen nose and ugly flushings; when one’s bread depends on one’s looks, what a trial that must be! I am heartily sorry for the good clever little soul.

Again made “a fly” at the cap; and again interrupted by Geraldine first, and then Mr Brookfield. Went with Geraldine to Sackville Street to her dentist.Either Clarke and Rodgers, Henry Jones, or the John Herring Parkinsons, father and son, at respectively 5, 23, and 36 Sackville St., Piccadilly. Mr Bridges and his unutterable randy of an Irish wifeProbably William Bridges of Mitre Insurance; see TC to JF, 6 Dec. Mrs. Bridges not further identified. at tea this evening. A woman that makes one quite poorly. I have heard several samples of wit today which I meant in hearing them to write in my journal, and lo! they have “lost themselves, quite.” This however I remember; When Charles 1st was living at Holyrood;Probably when he had his belated Scottish coronation, 1633, at Holyrood, the royal palace in Edinburgh. He came to the throne, 1625, and had his English coronation that year. The Scots were irritated by its lateness and its Episcopalian form. he used to amuse himself in shooting sparrows!—and the wee boys of the neighbourhood got into the way of attending him in his sport—and would cry out to him “Eh King! King,! look! There’s a sparrow!”
7th— — — first hiatus.

9th (Sunday) Sat in the house all day. Mr Neuberg in the evening—uglier than ever! What will that man come to?— “His Excellency” Robert Macintosh came in late, and brought new blood into our stagnation Geraldine most of the day with me.

10th Walked to Brook Street to the dyers—Unidentified. dined (Geraldine and I) at Darwins, and went with Mrs Wedgwood and Mr Tait to Julien’s— “Oh my! how expensive”! and what an infernal noise!Louis Jullien (1812–60), conductor and composer. The first part of his concert, Royal Italian Opera House, Covent Garden (advertised Times, 10 Dec.), was a “Beethoven Festival,” the second a miscellaneous performance, which included the “New Grand Quadrille of the Fall of Sebastopol” (one of many quadrilles composed by Jullien), assisted by military bands. and what a headach from it! I drank six tumblers of cold water on coming home

In a great hurryscurry all morning—letter about the Toys (“God particularly damn them”!)Coterie speech; see 27:305JWC to TC, 25 Sept. 1852. to be written to my Lady. dress to be fitted on—all before half past twelve, when I started by appointment to lunch with Miss Williams Wynn. Home only in time to dress for dinner at the Wedgwoods, where were NewmanFrancis William Newman (1805–97; ODNB), who had been Edward C. Sterling’s guardian; see 19:9JWC to HW, 9 Sept. 1845. and James Martineau whom I hadnt seen these six years—

Oh dear I wish this Grange business were well over It occupies me (the mere preparation for it) to the exclusion of all quiet thoughts and placid occupation (reading novels for instance—) To have to care for my dress at this time of day, more than I ever did when young and pretty and happy (god bless me! to think that I was once all that!) on penalty of being regarded as a blot on the Grange gold and azureThe colors of the shield in the Ashburton coat of arms. is really too bad. Ach gott! If we had been left in the sphere of life we belong to how much better it would have been for us—in many ways!

12th Off early to shop. What a lot of little trumpery things it takes to make me into a “Woman of England“—Cf. Sarah Ellis, The Women of England (1838); see 24:259JWC to JRS, 30 Sept. 1849. for a month! Met Miss Farrer coming here, and lunched at her house on my way to Mr Tait’s where I had appointed Lady A’s ex-Lady’s Maid to meet me and help about the Toys. Waited in vain for her an hour and quarter! Walked home in a rage—re infecta [nothing done], but got my fan (!) from the Mender, and bought a warm petticoat. Also left a message for SadlerHe was to help with the presents for the Grange; see TC to Lady ALA, 15 Dec. at Bath House. Consoled myself after tea with a “thrilling” Novel called The White Chief.Thomas Mayne Reid, The White Chief: A Legend of Northern Mexico, 3 vols. (1855).

13th Mrs StrachanUnidentified; possibly someone from Smithson & Straker, milliners and dressmakers, 17 Sackville St., Piccadilly. to fit on a white waistcoat and Kate Sterling, with a heavy cold in her head. Obliged to hurry her off that I might keep an appointment with old Mrs Farrer—Geraldine with me, and Miss Anderton there.

Colonel Sterling arrived this morning. Actually arrived! And now—what next? Will he come to see me? Yes?— No?—probably no. He comes for one fortnight and we go, on Monday, for a month! No time for indecisions!

14th Yes. The Colonel has come, but I was out. He staid an hour with Mr C, and engaged to dine here tomorrow. Either he still cares for me,Cf. 29:194JWC to MR, 7 Nov. 1854. enough to desire to see me once more—or he has found the centre of indifferenceSee Tarr, Sartor 127. and likes to show it. “Likes to show it“—? that is a questionable liking. When one is really and heartily indifferent; one is not at the pains to parade it—one parades nothing that one really and heartily is. the being it is enough for one,—can be left on its own basis. It is only what one is but halfly, unwillingly, that one tries (and vainly) to confirm oneself in, by making a show of it to “others.”
Tomorrow I shall see in the first five minutes how it is with him, on my subject, Ay! and much good may that do me!
A month at the Grange where I drank a gargle! On my return home sprained my side.See JWC to David DavidsonDD, 2 Feb. 1856 (vol. 31). Recovered from that I took cold.

Heavens!— My poor dear Journal! I have used you shamefully! I took you to comfort me in a time of need—something to hold on to in the darkness and loneliness; and the first will o’ wisp (of distraction) that crossed my path, away I went after it—full drive towards the bottomless quagmire, without even a goodby to you my poor Journal! as if you had been merely so much waste paper that might be taken to light the fire with; for any further use that was in you, or for anything I cared! Pardon dear Journal! I return to you penitent and punished. What more can I say? Ah! and you are so good! so discreet! are content always that bygones should be bygones. I don’t need then with you to begin, where I left off—which would be an insuperable obstacle to beginning at all. We are now at the 24th of March 1856. and from this point of time let us resume our daily intercourse without looking back—looking back was not intended by nature, evidently; from the fact that our eyes are in our faces and not in our hind-heads. Look straight before you then Jane Carlyle, and if possible not over the heads of things either, away into the distant vague! Look, above all, at “the duty nearest hand”A maxim of Goethe’s; see 5:149–50TC to HI, 23 Aug. 1830. and what’s more do it! Ah the spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak!Matt. 26:41. and four weeks of illness have made mine weak as water. No galloping over London as in “seven league-boots”Cf. “The Story of Jack the Giant Killer.” for me at present! Today I walked with effort one little mile and thought it a
great feat! But if the strength has gone out of me so also has the unrest; I can sit, and lie even, very patiently doing nothing. To be sure I am “always going on with the story in my head” (as poor PauletMark Étienne Paulet (d. 1850; see 13:189TC to JWC, 19 July 1841). expressed it); but even that has taken a dreamy contemplative character, and excites no emotions “to speak of.” In fact Sleep has come to look to me the highest virtue, and the greatest happiness—that is, good sleep—untroubled, beautiful, like a child’s— Ah me!

I have done something today which I wonder it never occurred to me to do before— I have put a child to school. It is surely a charity that, which anybody in the rank of a gentlewoman can afford—and it gives no trouble, and is at the same time an unquestionable benifit to the receiver— I wonder I never thought of it, till I heard Hanah Freeman’sPresumably the widow of Freeman the cooper (d. 1851; see 26:267TC to JWC, 11 Dec. 1851), who sometimes helped JWC with the cooking (see 27:227JWC to TC, 14 Aug. 1852, where unidentified). little boy was becoming a plague to the neighbourhood; Hanah being “too poor to pay his schooling.” The Dame I have placed him with is 74 years old and brisk as a bee. much brisker than I am. Mem: to persuade her into letting a little fresh air into her schoolroom, which would be a great advantage; I was ready to faint from three minutes of it—had to beg her to come out with me into the passage.

A pupil of Dr Parr’sDr. Samuel Parr (1747–1825); see Carlyle, Reminiscences 298, 300–301. came in to him one day, and said laughing, “I have just passed three men in one gig; it reminded me of The Trinity“— “Pooh!” said the Dr “you are a fool. If you had seen one man in three gigs; that might have reminded you of the Trinity”! The wind has blown strongly from the East today, and I have not ventured out. For the rest my activity has confined itself to talking; and even in that I have exceeded my poor strength First I speculated with Geraldine then made conversation with Eliza SnowdenSee 29:231JWC to ESN, 4 Jan. 1855, and Carlyle, Reminiscences 61–62. who took this inauspicious day for her yearly visit to me; bringing with her my tall god-daughter and a son, a fine intelligent boy of fifteen,Her children are not further identified; according to TC, she had “six or seven children” (Reminiscences 336). who when I had kissed his mother and sister held up his face to be kissed too! the same ceremony at parting! to the astonishment of Mr Tait who had come in towards the end of their visit of two hours! Alone with him I fairly broke down—lost my wits—lost my voice—thought him every minute more like the figure-head on a Thames Steamer—and felt an inclination to scream! So has gone my day— “Le plus grand malheur est bon à quelque chose” [The greatest
misfortune is good for something].Proverbial. I have just read that; certainly not for the first time; but for the first time I have taken it in, as a consolation—of a sort.

Four or five years ago John Robertson brought here a Man of whom, it seems, I said (aside) to Robertson; “that is a born natural; where did you pick him up?“—four or five days ago Kate Sterling brought here the same man to introduce to me as her fiancé!!–Alexander J. Ross (1819–87), liberal theologian and writer; educ. Edinburgh Univ.; minister, Free Church of Scotland, Langholm, Dumfriesshire, 1844–47; moved to Brighton, 1848, to become minister of Hanover Church; left the Free Church, 1852; became an unattached minister, the Pavilion Chapel, Brighton; lectured frequently at Brighton Mechanic’s Inst.; ordained into the Church of England, 1865. He met Kate Sterling at F. D. Maurice’s house, 5 Russell Sq., London. The Carlyles shared the Sterling family’s dislike of Ross. He admired TC: “the works of Carlyle perhaps exerted a stronger influence over him than any other [at univ.]. … Carlyle first opened out before his wondering eyes new regions not bounded by the Westminster Confessions” (Adelaide Ross, Memoir of Alexander J. Ross[1888] 7). On TC’s death, Ross wrote: “his profoundly religious utterances have struck deeply into the hearts of his contemporaries, and I cannot but think that the modern larger light and liberty to Scotland are mainly owing to him” (Ross 251). “what a waste!” (as Dwerkanauth said of the sixteen girls burnt in a sutteeDwarkanath Tagore (1794–1846), wealthy Hindu entrepreneur; in Britain, 1842–43, 1845; see also 28:70–71JWC to HW, 12 March 1853 where he is unidentified.)— That brave, passionate-hearted girl the wife of such a nauseous creature!—nauseous is the word for him! Oh dear oh dear! what misery awaits her, when she shall awake from her bewitchment,—bedevilment!Cf. introduction to and the last paragraph of Simple Story, 182JWC’s "Simple Story of My Own First Love", 194. I never saw a case of love that made more in favour of Dr Carlyle’s opinion; “love is merely a disease of the nerves—a mild delirium”! Really one should pray for the gift not only “to see ourselves as others see us”Cf. Robert Burns, “To a Louse.” but also to see our Lovers as others see them.

Today it has blown knives and files! a cold, rasping, savage day; excruciating for sick nerves. Dear Geraldine, as if she would contend with the very elements on my behalf, brought me a bunch of violets, and a bouquet of the loveliest most fragrant flowers!
Talking with her all I have done or could do. Mr Fairie called but I despatched him in no time.

“Have mercy upon me o Lord; for I am weak: O Lord heal me; for my bones are vexed. My soul is also sore vexed; But then, o Lord, how long? Return o Lord deliver my soul; oh save me for thy mercies sake.”Ps. 6:1–4.

In bed till after midday, overpowered with the morphia I had to take in the night. Thereby missed the call of Miss Williams Wynn. Today, the sun has shone!! I walked, slowly, by my own unaided strength to Mrs Hawkes’s,Emilie Hawkes was unhappily married and was later to divorce Sydney Hawkes. Her father, William Ashurst (1792–bap. 1791?, d. 1855; ODNB), had d., Oct. 1855, and she was worried about Mazzini and Italy’s future. Mazzini wrote, 20 May: “When I see you not only ill, but morally sinking, I feel lost, cramped and wishing for action, not for Italy’s sake. … I feel dear that I have been de trop amongst you. Still now, think and dream if possible, only of what I am trying to do in Italy, and do not say that your blessing can do no good, but all the same no harm. It would do so much good if it would come from a calm and strong soul, from a sad but not despairing sister” (Mazzini’s Letters to an English Family, ed. E. F. Richards [1920] 1:23–24, 2:34, 37). and found her, as white as a ghost, painting at a little comic picture for the Exhibition. She had had a strange sort of seizure. She was standing one day with her arms up, combing her long hair, and was suddenly fixed, rigid, in her attitude. She was perfectly conscious, and “felt as if she must fall”; but “couldn’t move or cry.” This lasted, as well as she could compute for some four or five minutes. Afterwards she “trembled violently” and “had been nervous ever since”; tho she had “never had a feeling of nervousness in her life before.” Poor woman! she thought to defy her complication of griefs; “it shouldn’t break her heart,” “shouldn’t depress her spirits“—but all the while it was destroying her nervous system.

Mr C took Nero out with him to night, and half an hour after he opened the door with his latch key, and called in; “is that vermin come back?“— Having received my horrified, “No!“—he hurried off again; and for twenty minutes I was in the agonies of one’s dog lost—my heart beating up into my ears— At last I heard Mr C’s feet in the street and (oh joy!) heard him gollaring at something—and one knew what the little bad something was!— Ach!—“we could have better spared a better dog”!Cf. 1 Henry IV 5.4.

No outgoing for me today—too cold, and my chest (as they call it) too sensitive. Darwin came and contrary to his habits told me a story—of some length.— Here it is— A young English woman, with virtues and talents went to be a governess in Germany, where she “gave the highest satisfaction”; till unfortunately she got herself seduced, under promise of marriage (of course); and a baby ensued. Whether the baby lived or died I don’t know. But the young woman gathered herself together, returned to England and managed to get the charge of a Nobleman’s children, and house; the Parents
being absent on the continent. For more than a year she filled this situation to the high contentment of all concerned. Was regarded as “a Treasure.” But the affair of the baby lay heavy on her conscience, and one day she presented herself to the Minister of the Parish, and asked; was it not her duty to confide that fact to her employers. What could a Minister say (whatever he might think) but that it was her duty—accordingly she “made a clean breast” to the Lady who had engaged her, the children’s guardian, in the absence of the Parents; and what could she do (whatever she might wish) but “feel it her duty” to dismiss her— She was “very sorry” but “being responsible to the Parents, &c, &c“—so this martyr to conscience found herself planted;Presumably in the sense of being moved to a new place rather than in being settled. her only family even rejecting her.

Darwin thought her sublime. Geraldine and I called her weak. Having committed a fault or error—what you will—; it behoved her we said to accept the consequences thereof patiently and bravely, in so far as they were inevitable; and as every failure had a lesson in it, it behoved her to read the lesson in hers, and turn it to practical account. But holding herself responsible for her past to people who had to do only with her present, and pouring herself out in confession, to her own injury and the discomfort of all about her—that we could recognise neither obligation nor sublimity in; only narrowness—and weakliness and woman’s commonest defect, a want of reticence.

Meanwhile this Lady has got into the philanthropic hands of John Allan,Unidentified. the Protector of Unfortunate Females, Juvenile Delinquents et hoc genus, and has been shown as a Martyr to “honourable women not a few“— whom she has intrestedCf. Acts 17:12; coterie speech; cf. 15:135JWC to JW, 19 Oct. 1842; “intrested“: thus in MS. to a pitch of enthusiasm by declaring that should any Husband offer himself in Australia; (they speak of sending her to Australia) she would tell him of her ‘misfortune’ the very first thing. Bravo!

Today I have written a letter and two notes—and read all sorts of odds and ends in The Polar Star.The Polar Star and Extractor, or, Universal Repertorium of Literature, Science and the Arts; comprehending … the whole of the instructive and amusing articles from all the reviews, magazines, and journals, 10 vols. (1829–32).

I insert a letterAttached beside this entry: “33 Queen Street / Brompton / March 28th 56 / My dear Cousin / It is hoped the day will arrive when I shall be able to send you a less gloomy account of myself than I have done of late so here I have inflicted on you a letter—I believe you will be sorry to hear that I have been confined to my room for the last fortnight suffering torture in my left side from an accident & Dr Anderson who attends me has been to do little more than soothe the pain with opiates. Added to this I have had a bitter disappointment in not having succeeded in obtaining before Easter the Master’s Report respecting the suit in Chancery in which I am interested. It is supposed it will be ready soon after these holidays & then I shall be relieved from much. In the mean time I know not how to get the means of keeping body and soul together—and I now trespass on your generosity & kindness by begging you to send me a loan of half a sovereign, by complying with this request you will render me a great benefit & I will very soon return it with my other debts to you and more gratitude than I can express. Will you kindly send an answer to this house where I have been for a year & a half. My Landlord is a very poor man or I should not be in such sad want— It has been dreadful to be kept such a length of time daily almost expecting this business to be got through & the continual disappointments quite enough with other things I have suffered to break anybody’s heart [two words illegible]. / Excuse this hurried note. I am in agony at this moment. Wishing you every blessing you can desire / I am Ever / My dear Cousin / Yours Most Affectly / J. A. Baillie / Mrs Carlyle / Chelsea.” received this morning from “my handsome Cousin,” Capt Baillie—a remarkable document for those who knew of him in his days
of London Celebrity; when he was Chief Dandy, spending his Capital at the rate of fifteen thousand a year, on fine clothes, horses carriages and King Charles spaniels. I wish I had preserved (that I might have placed it beside this letter) his Taylors bill as it figured in the newspapers some 25 years ago: and an Article upon him in Frasers Magazine a few years later, in which he was described as “a mixture of Mars and Adonis,” “perfuming the air of Rotten Row with his embroidered handkerchief, as he rode along on his splendid black horse.“—Both untraced. For JWC’s first meeting with James Baillie in 1824, see 3:149–50JBW to TC, 17 Sept. 1824; for an earlier lecture to him about his behavior, see 15:70–71JWC to JW, 6 Sept. 1842. See also K. J. Fielding, “Captain James Belial Baillie—Jane Carlyle’s Wicked Cousin: Unpublished Pages from the Reminiscences,” Carlyle Newsletter 4 (spring 1983): 2–11.

And now it has come to borrowing half sovereigns, with him. Alas! and he had talents as well as good looks; and a heart “not bad” by anymeans. I went myself during an hour of sunshine to assure myself he was really ill; before sacrificing another halfsovereign, which as Tommy GriersonPossibly a relative of James Aitken; see 17:171TC to JCA, 12 Nov. 1843, and 216TC to JCA, 26 Dec. 1843; or of TC’s maternal aunt Jean (d. 1810), m. John Grierson (d. 1828); see Marrs 95. said of the halfpenny he bestowed on a beggar, “was a great deal for a wee fellow like me!” I found him in a poor but decent looking house in a mean street. Having sent my name by his Landlord I was shown up; and the mixture of Mars and Adonis received me at his door, with as stately a grace, as he had ever displayed on his famous Black Horse. He is still very handsome, and his dress tho’ threadbare was as clean and peculiar as of old. a sort of short blouse made of an old yellow Indian shawl much darned, had taken place of the fifty-guinea brocade dressing-gown. Half of his shirt sleeves were left uncovered, tho of the coarsest cotton; but they were white and well starched. The room he was in, very small, served evidently for parlour bed room and kitchen— In
one corner was a fourposted bed, the posts rising desolately to the ceiling, without a morsel of curtain— The floor was well scowered, with a bit of darned carpet in the middle. Two or three deal chairs,—one of them a sort of arm-one, with a bed-pillow in it without cover, for the Invalid,—a table with a cover, on which lay a book (one of Gleig’s)George Robert Gleig (1796–1888; ODNB; see 5:82TC to JAC, 19 March 1830), former army officer; chaplain gen. of the armed forces, 1844–75; journalist and writer of works of military interest. and other civilized items—some cooking utensils a basin stand— Ah heaven! There was not even a toilet, on which to have laid out his beautiful gold & silver dressing-case, had it been to the fore! a very thrifty poorperson’s fire with a large brass-nail knocked into the mantleshelf—to serve the purpose of roasting. All that I noticed—and I dont think there was much besides—and on this ruins of his Carthage sat “the elegant Jim Baillie” doing the Marius of Dandyism as well as it could be done— Not a word of apology for his environment—not an alusion to it—not even recognition of it by look—A more perfectly unembarrassed courteous reception I never met in my life! I asked where was his—“wife”? He answered “why, here to be sure!” Then I understood that air of comfort in the midst of exigence! only a woman could have compassed it; and even a woman could have compassed it only thro love! “Ah,” I said “I might have known it, by seeing how well you are cared for“— “Yes” he said, “that poor soul has had a sore time of it trying to keep me straight; for five & twenty years now I have been a heavy handful to her, and she has never wearied never relaxed—god bless her! there is not a better woman”! and the fine eyes filled with tears till they ran over. That was his only approach to sentiment.

Poor woman indeed! ruined by him in fortune and reputation and still holding on in her unselfish love. And the virtuos would frown on her—she is not his wife.— I wish I had seen her to shake hands with her, and express my—admiration!—His common-law wife is not further identified. A. Carlyle attaches a note here in his typescript of the Journal: “James Baillie, sank lower & lower, and finally became a regular pensioner on Carlyle’s bounty. He sent him regularly £10 each half year from 1866 or 7 till Baillie’s death; and afterwards continued the payments to his ‘widow,’ in the same manner, till he himself died. He also left informal instructions that the £20 should be paid to her biennially till her death. Carlyle’s Executors paid the first half-year’s instalment due in March 1881, but could not recognise the informal instructions further. Carlyle’s Niece (my late Wife) carried out, at her own expense, his wishes in this respect, for about two years, when Mrs. Baillie died. / Carlyle with his usual delicacy, took much pains to conceal from the Baillies that he was their benefactor. The money passed through various hands (always cautioned ‘to observe the same veiled terms’) before it reached its destination. In my time the cheques were sent to the Parish Minister at Streatham, the Revd Wodehouse Raven. / A.C.”

“My Dear,” said Mr C this evening, “your visit to your handsome Cousin to day has done you no good.“— I dare say I shan’t sleep for it. But anything that
takes one’s sympathies out of oneself is to be sought rather than avoided—is it not?
My cousin MaggieMargaret Welsh (b. 1821). arrived at dinner-time to stay a week or fortnight. I dont well see my way thro it—“unaccustomed as I am to public speaking”!
30th Sunday

When I receive (as they call it—tho, to my idea, there is more of giving than receiving—one gives oneself—in the form of minced-meat!) First came Plattnauer, long before the general calling hour, and took me for a little walk in Battersea FieldsMarshy common land on the south side of the Thames, opp. Chelsea; see 16:56–57TC to JOST, 23 Feb. 1843. (The little cousin had been disposed of at church with dear considerate Geraldine) The sun shone brightly, and Plattnauer talked pleasantly so brüderlich [brotherly]! He told me the end of the Romance of Major Tighu and Madame Schmid—Both unidentified. that is to say the latest news of them. The Major was become “a shepherd on Horseback“— Madame Schmid was on the streets!—(of Melbourne)” sic transit—!“Sic transit gloria mundi” [So passes away the glory of the world], Thomas à Kempis (1380–1471), Imitation of Christ. He told me also how the grande passion between Herr Schüzd and Miss BellBoth unidentified. had gone—to the dogs utterly—the general recipients of grand passions

lg.l: “O Waly Waly love is bonnie
A little while when it is new
But when it’s auld
It waxeth cauld

And melts awa like morning dew”Scots ballad, verse 2; there are many English and Scots versions; of uncertain date, it is said to be about Lady Barbara Erskine (d. 1690), deserted by her husband, James, 2d marquis of Douglas (1646?–1700), after false allegations of infidelity against her; first pbd.: Tea-table Miscellany, ed. Allan Ramsay (Edinburgh, 1724); see also G. F. Graham, The Songs of Scotland (Edinburgh, 1848) 101.

div1.p: Beautiful verse! sweet and sad, like barley-sugar dissolved in tears! about the “morning dew,” however? I should say goes out like candle snuff would be a truer simile—only that wouldnt suit the rhyme.

After Plattnauer came Countess Pepoli Mr Tait, Mr Barlow, MrsSee 28:21JWC to KS, 28 Jan. 1853; Mrs. Anderton not further identified. and Miss Anderton, and in the evening we had Fitzgerald who was charming in his genial sleepy way.

This living continually in the presence of a fellowcreature is very trying—a female fellowcreature too and so—what shall I say?—undeveloped! I wouldnt for a great deal, my good little goldenhaired Cousin, that you knew how much you fatigue me!
I took her this forenoon to call with me on Miss Wilson and on the Farrers. Geraldine kindly invited her for the evening.

Another letter from James BaillieAttached beside 1 April entry: “Queen Street / March 31st: 1856 / My dear cousin / I was very much gratified by your kind visit on Saturday, during the long time I have been in this humble abode you are the only visitor I have ever received, & you see I can accommodate myself to my circumstances— / I feel it was very kind in you to come so promptly to my aid & hope you will not think it a trouble to do what you can to help me to get on till this sadly protracted Chancery business, is concluded. / I would do anything in the world that would be the means of saving me from the necessity of applying for loans to my friends— I think in the course of our conversation you said something about the possibility of getting some papers to be copied. If such is the case I will be glad to set to work cheerfully & energetically although I know the remuneration is very trifling—and I shall be very grateful to you if you will let me hear from you if anything of the work can be managed. / I hope this will find you in good health. My side is rather less painful today, your visit did me good. / Believe me Ever / yours most Affectly / J. A. Baillie / Mrs Carlyle / Cheyne Row.”
Meanwhile I read The Polar Star.

Began the day by making an April fool of the gentleman next door.Perhaps Chalmers, 4 Cheyne Row. He had defied me. My young Lady off to “the Gulden Lecture”;The Golden Lectures (pbd: Henry Melvill, The Golden Lectures [1850–57] 7 vols.), a series of Tuesday morning sermons given at St. Margaret’s Church, Lothbury, E London, by the Rev. Henry Melvill (1798–1871; ODNB), chaplain to Queen Victoria and canon of St. Paul’s from 26 April. The lecture of 1 April was “The Resurrection Principle.” what ever that may be!
Called on Mrs Lowe, who embraced me, and gave me coffee. Walked a good spell today; Thank Heaven my strength is returning.

2d My young Lady in bed till dinner time, ill from her yesterdays fatigues of pleasure hunting. Dr Carlyle and his ward the sailorboyHenry Watt. at dinner. A most wearing uncomfortable day—Mr C “bilious,” and aggravating. Geraldine gone to Lady Brooke at Sydenham. Young women—that is young Ladies are wonderful upon my honour! It never seems to occur to Maggie that elderly people may have things they like better to do than leading her about. And she
makes conversation for me—me! yes and for Mr Carlyle himself, as if she were sure we must like it;
4th —
5th —
6th !
8th !!
9th ——

11th I really couldn’t help it! There was no time for you my Journal—poor passive friend! In the mornings there was Maggie to be looked after, and at nights I was so dished! Now I am alone again; I took my little cousin to the Liverpool train the day before yesterday and her sweet good face smiling on me thro’ tears as she shot away went to my heart like a remorse. But could I help being so weak and nervous that the continual presence of a fellow creature especially a young lighthearted fellow creature irritated and fagged me beyond measure? all the more that in common kindness I had to repress any outward expression of my feelings!

Today I called on “my Lady”;Ashburton. come to town for the season—she was perfectly civil—for a wonder. Today also I lighted on an interesting man.Unidentified. It was in our Baker’s shop. While the Baker was making out my bill he addressed some counsel to a dark little man with a wooden leg, and a basket of small wares—that made me look at the man to watch its effect on him. “Ill tell you what to do” said this Jesuit of a Baker “go and join some Methodist Chapel for six months; make yourself agreeable to them, and you’ll soon have friends that will help you in your object” The man of the wooden leg said not a word, but looked hard in the bakers face, with a half perplexed half amused and wholly disagreeing expression. “Nothing like religion” went on the tempter “for gaining a man friends— Dont you think so Mam”? (catching my eye on him.) “I think said I that whatever this man’s object may be he is not likely to be benefited in the long run by constituting himself a hypocrite”! The man’s black eyes flashed on me a look of thanks and approbation. “Oh”
said the Baker I dont mean him to be a hypocrite—but truly religious you know!”— “If this man will be advised by me, I said, he will keep himself clear of the true religion, that is purposely put on some morning to make himself friends.” “Yes” said the poor man pithily “not that at no price”!— In my enthusiasm at his answer and the manner of it, I gave him—sixpence! and inquired into his case— He had been a baker for some time—met with an accident and “had to let his leg be taken; after trying for eight years to keep it meanwhile his grandfather died leaving him a small property worth 40£ a year—which he was still kept out of for want of money to prove his right to it. I did not understand the law part of the story; but undertook to get some honest lawyer to look at his papers and give him advice for nothing. I called on Mr Chalmers in the evening and he has promised to do this piece of benevolence for me.
12th Sorted up accounts &c— Called at the Contessa’s. Read a Novel called the Ring & the VeilJ. A. Saint John, The Ring and the Veil, 3 vols. (1856). till two of the morning— And life is short!
13th Sunday

Walked with Plattnauer in the new Battersea Park.Battersea Fields had become notorious for illegal racing, drinking, and gambling; it was hoped that the new park, made in part of the fields, would regulate behavior and provide a place for healthy exercise; designed by Sir James Pennethorne (1801–71; ODNB). Work began in 1852 when 750,000 tons of material excavated from Surrey Docks was used to raise the level of the site; opened to the public, 1854, and officially opened, 1858. Received till dinner time. Geraldine Mr Barlow Mr Tait. Mr Fitzgerald at tea— Mr B told me a new version of the eleventh commandment, “Thou shallt not be found out The Germans make the eleventh commandment Lass dich nicht verblüffen [Thou shalt not be deceived]

14th Lay on the sofa most of the day feeling “too ill for anything“— Nevertheless towards seven o’clock took myself up stairs, and dressed myself very fine, and was driven to Bath House to a dinner party. The Twisletons Milnes ‘The Bear,’ Goldwin SmithGoldwin Smith (1823–1910; ODNB), controversial liberal politician and religious thinker; writer for the Saturday Review. and Delane. Came home with virtues own reward in shape of a sore throat—my throat fairly made sore by telling Lord A French Criminal Trials all the evening out of a book he hadn’t seen. He was so unwell! and since he was there; instead of where he should have been viz: in his bed, I “felt it my duty” to amuse him without letting him talk.MS A ends here.

p.note: MS B starts with this entry.

div1.p: I am really very feeble and ailing at present. And my ailment is of a sort that I understand neither the ways nor outlooks of; so that the positive suffering is complicated with dark apprehensions. Alas, alas and there is nobody I care to tell about it! not one! poor ex-spoilt Child that I am!

To keep up the appearances of being alive is just as much as I can manage. Every day I get up with the wish to do ever so many things; but my wishes are no longer “presentiment of my powers“—if they ever were so! At the days end I find I have merely got thro’ it, better or worse; not employed it; all strength for work of any sort being used up in bearing the bodily pressure, without crying out. I am in arrears with even “the needle work of the Family.” In fact, look at it which way I will, I dont see why, If I did die, I should “regret the loss of myself” (as Mr Davis’s beggarman said)Both unidentified.

Geraldine and I went to day to St Lukes to witness a Confirmation performed by the Bishop of Oxford.Samuel Wilberforce. Heavens, how well he did it! Even I was almost touched by the tears in his voice and the adorable tenderness of his exhortation!About seven lines have been cut out by TC; a piece of paper has been attached over the gap, on which he has written: “repeatedly spoke of this,—with such humour & ingenuous grace; descriptive, too, as a mirror!—.”
Wrote a long letter to St Thomas;“Erskine of Linlathen” (TC’s note above the line). in answer to one received from him the other day—such a darling letter! (I mean his not mine)

Went with Geraldine to look at the Marlborough House picturesThe collection of paintings by British artists, including Turner and Constable, bequeathed to the National Gallery by Robert Vernon (1774–1849), was housed, 1849–57, in the ground floor of Marlborough House, Pall Mall. Marlborough House had been the home of dowager Queen Adelaide (1792–1849; ODNB) and was put to various public uses until Edward, prince of Wales (1841–1910; ODNB), was old enough to use it as his official residence. but was too tired and sick to do anything but sit about on chairs. Came home half dead and lay on [on the Sofa till Miss Williams Wynn came to tea; “very much detached;”“[P]hrase of a book we used to see” (TC’s note inserted above “detached”). Fanny Burney, Evelina (1778) 2:192. as that Lady generally is now. Hithering and thithering among
the Stump-orators of every denominatn; threat—]Words in square brackets copied by TC onto the piece of paper attached over the gap (see n. 196). threatening to deteriorate into a mere dingle-doosie in fact!“[N]o finer metaphor in the world, to signify an aimless, restless, uselessly showy person! see Note above” (TC’s note on JWC’s MS). TC has written this “Note” on his inserted piece of paper: “‘Dingle-dingle-doosie, / The cat’s a’ loosie, / The dog’s i’ the well; / And Dad’s awa’ to Edinbro’ / To buy the Bairn a bell!’— Nurse takes a small splint or quill of half-burnt wood from the fire; whirls it abt, so that the red end of it makes circles or meandering ribbons (all of fire to the child’s eye) singing as above, crooning.”

18th Baked! Went with Geraldine to see the Chelsea Commission at work on Lord Lucan.George Charles Bingham (1800–1888; ODNB), 3d earl of Lucan; field marshal. The reports of the committee of inquiry into the conduct of the Crimean War, June 1855 and Jan. 1856, led by Sir John McNeill (1795–1883; ODNB) and Sir Alexander Murray Tulloch (1803–64; ODNB), blamed officers for their careless distribution of supplies and general neglect of troops. Lucan was accused of delaying the building of temporary stables for cavalry horses, many of which died as a result. He and others resented the conclusions of the commission. Lucan said the Ministry of War and sec. of the treasury had tried to make him and other officers scapegoats for mismanagement at home (7 Feb., Reply of Major General, the Earl of Lucan, Chelsea Inquiry [1856] 60). He wrote to Lord Panmure asking for a further examination and the opportunity to give his own evidence (Parliamentary Papers XL [1856]: 321). Under pressure, the govt. convened a second board of inquiry, which began at the Royal Hospital, Chelsea, 3 April. The commissioners, composed of officers, with Gen. Sir John Colborne (1778–1863), 1st Baron Seaton, as president, disputed the McNeill-Tulloch report and exonerated Lucan and other officers, saying that Lucan “used every exertion to meet the peculiar difficulties he had to contend with” and that he could not be charged with neglect (Parliamentary Papers XXI [1856]: vi). Could not get near enough to hear. The Commissioners looked very sleepy and Lord Lucan very weary. No wonder! Charles Villiers was siting among the red coatsVilliers as judge-advocate gen. and privy councillor advised the crown on military law and ensured that military discipline was carried out strictly according to the law. He was present at the hearings, 18 April, wearing judicial red robes. looking like Mephistophales. And the back of Lord Lucan’s head is bald—hair black. These are all the particulars I gleaned. The large Hall was beautifully carpeted and fitted up for the occasion; and the Table at which the Commissioners sat was covered with a white table cloth; as if for the Lords Supper— How sick I have been all this day! “Be thankful you are not in Purgatory”! (as the Annandale man told his complaining friend)Sandy Macleod; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 22.

Wrote a business letter to Mr Adamson.Robert Adamson. Dragged myself to Sloan Street, to see Mrs Hawks. She looked more suffering than myself; and as usual made
melancholy fun of her sufferings. She told me that Mrs Hooper, the Authoress of The House of Raby,Jane Margaret Hooper, formerly Winnard, The House of Raby; or, Our Lady of Darkness, 3 vols. (1854). is going blind. Poor creature! All her faculties needed to make ends meet; and going blind.

Read Miss Mulochs new novel John HalifaxDinah Maria Mulock (1826–87; ODNB; see 24: 288–89JWC to JF, 13 Nov. 1849), John Halifax, Gentleman (1856). all the evening. They call it her best book; I find it sickly and rather wearisome.It was her 6th and most popular novel, to be reprinted many times. The wonder is that the poor young woman can write at all with her body all “gone to smithers”!
20th Sunday

Plattnauer in the morning. I was too poorly for walking with him, so we talked intimately over the fire. Except Geraldine, no other callers. I fell asleep while Geraldine was here and again after she had gone! This weakness is incomprehensible—if I had any person, or any thing to take hold of, and lean my weight on!

Mr Neuberg at tea. But Mr C fled off to Bath House“Mrs. Carlyle herself was clearly not averse to going to Bath House any more than ‘Mr. C.’ During the few weeks covered by this part of her Journal she was there according to her own shewing no less than four times; and in addition she paid a visit of four or five days to Addiscombe” (A. Carlyle’s note on typescript). and walked him out. I would advise no man to creep into another’s favour by making himself “generally useful”; he is sure to get kicked out of it, when the other has got blasé on his subserviency. If one don’t like a man for what he is; neither will one ever like him for what he does for one, or gives one. Neither should any man—or woman—get up a quasi-liking for another on the ground of his subserviency—“obligingness“—and that sort of thing; for when the other has gained the end of his subserviency—a certain favour or at least toleration—he tires of being obliging, and sets up for himself, and complains perhaps, like the Colonel, that he is “made a convenience of”!
I feel weaklier everyday; and “my soul is also sore vexed“.— Oh “how long”?

I put myself in an omnibus, being unable to walk, and was carried to Islington and back again. What a good shilling’s worth of exercise! The Angel at Islington! It was there I was set down on my first arrival in London; and Mr C with Edward Irving was waiting to receive me.—In 1831; in fact, TC and John met JWC, not Edward Irving. Irving had visited them in the evening; see 6:7–8TCJWC to MAC, 6 Oct. 1831. “The past is past; and gone is gone!”

At night I sewed a lace border on the Mexican pocket handkerchief Mrs ArbucklePossibly the wife of Dr. Robert Arbuckle; see 8:218TC to JWC, 6 Oct. 1835. gave me; in the view of wearing it as a head-dress!

I heard a man explaning to another what “the Chelsea Commission” was after “They are trying to find out—and can’t, you see, for all they’re trying and trying, find out what they have gone and done!“— Ladies take their crochet work to the sittings of the Commission!!

Not up to even a ride in an Omnibus today. Mrs Twisleton came. Speaking of a complication that some people had said should have been righted in this way, and some in that way; “I wonder,” said the little practical woman, “that it never occurs to any body, that in such cases a little self-controul and a little self-denial would keep all straight.”
Miss Farrer dropt in before tea, and meeting Mr FergusJohn. staid the evening—

23d The Countess sat an hour with me in the morning. she is sure I “dont eat enough” I could not walk further today than half way to Sloan Square! Oh dear oh dear! this living merely to live is weary work!

24 Soon after breakfast I went by two Omnibuses to Hampstead; with Nero, and a book, and spent several hours sitting on the Heath, and riding in a donkey chair The pleasantest thing I have tried for some time and the fresh wind up there has revived me a little. Mr C told me at dinner that the unlikeliest of all living men to be met in the streets of London had got out of a carriage to speak to him in Piccaddilly, “an iron-grey man, with a bitter smile; who do you think”? “George Rennie”!JWC’s old Haddington admirer. I answered without a moments hesitation. And it was! and how on earth did I divine him? I had not a shadow of reason to believe he was not still Governor of the Falkland Islands!He had been gov., 1847–55. Not the shadow of a shadow of reason! And he was not “an iron-grey man” when I had last seen him.

25 while talking philosophy with Mr Barlow today, there drove up a carriage and I heard a voice inquiring if I were at home; which I knew; tho’ I had not heard it for ten years!—Mr Barlow I can see is trying to “make Mrs Carlyle
out”!That Barlow was attracted to JWC is shown by his letter to her, 29 July: “How often I thought of you during the last ten days!— Seven of them were passed in the country, in a place so far like Hampstead heath that it is on the top of a tolerably high hill: there was quite enough of resemblance between the two localities to remind me of what was often projected—our tea-drinking in a quiet Inn— How much my mind would have been enriched in recollections had that scheme been realized. … I want to hear you talk. … Do write to me no—I must first wait to see you again—I cannot hazard losing a letter from you. … That last day at your house! I might have staid indefinitely, so strongly was I under the impression that I should be your escort to Miss Jewsbury’s—and then I was thinking with such gratification of the possession of your photograph which is one of the best I know—I must give you [?] in return—and so it was that I hazarded spoiling your dinner and enraging your husband. How astounded any one of us would be at the amount of offence given, in the course of a moderately long life, in absolute unconsciousness! … Ever yours John Barlow” (MS: NLS 1774.86). (dont he wish he may get it?) what he witnessed today must have thrown all his previous observations into the wildest confusion. “The fact of being descended from John KnoxJWC was not descended from John Knox; see 16:41JWC to JW, 2 Feb. 1843, and 21:235TC to DL, 18 June 1847. had explained much in Mrs Carlyle he (Mr Barlow) hadn’t (he said to Geraldine) been able to make out.”Cf. William Forster’s reported response to JWC in 1849 (24:160JWC’s MAAN, 2 Aug. 1849). Did it explain for him my sudden change to day, when flinging my accustomed indifference and the “three thousand punctualities”Coterie speech, from the Chinese novel Two Fair Cousins. to the winds; I sprang into the arms of George Rennie and kissed him a great many times! Oh what a happy meeting! for he was as glad to see me, as I to see him. Oh it has done me so much good this meeting! My bright, whole-hearted, impulsive youth seemed conjured back by his hearty embrace. for certain; my late deadly weakness was conjured away! A spell on my nerves it had been; which dissolved in the unwonted feeling of gladness. I am a different woman this evening! I am well! I am in an atmosphere of home and long ago! George spoke to me of ShandyJWC and Grace Welsh’s pet dog; see 4:190TCJWC to MAC, 17 Feb. 1827. while he caressed Nero! It was only when I looked at his tall Son he brought with him, who takes after his Mother,JWC had thought Mrs. Rennie “a perfect fool” in 1834; see 7:253JWC to EA, 1 Aug. 1834. The son is not further identified. that I could realize the life time that lay between our talks in the drawing room at Haddington, and our talk here in Cheyne Row Chelsea.
Dear me! I shouldnt wonder if I were too excited to sleep, however.

All right! I slept all the better for my little bit of happiness—and I really am strengthened body and soul I have walked more today than anyday these two months George said his wife would call today, to arrange a meeting at their house but she hasn’t come.

My poor man of the wooden leg brought tonight his “papers“—(a copy of his Grandfathers will and other documents) to be examined by Mr Chalmers. The result was hopeless. Not a shadow of claim on his part to dispute the present disposition of the property and moreover the property like a highland man’s breeches.Possibly meaning nonexistent, as were Highland men’s breeches before the kilt was proscribed in 1746 after the Jacobite rebellion. Cf. also John Galt, The Provost (Edinburgh, 1822) 204. I gave him a shilling and advice to put the thing out of his head, which of course he wont do.
Sunday

27 All the world has been down at Chelsea today hearing Charles Kingsley preach!—The Rev. Charles Kingsley (1819–75; ODNB; see 27:39827:biographical note) wrote to a friend, 27 Feb.: “I am going to preach on ‘Saved by Hope’ to my people, on Sunday, and also when I preach for my father at Chelsea, on (D.V.) April 27, for the District Visiting Society” (Fanny Kingsley, Charles Kingsley: His Letters and Memories of his Life [1877] 1:465). His father, Charles Kingsley Sr. (1781–1860; see 28:152TC to JAC, 20 May 1853), was the rector of St. Luke’s Church, Chelsea. Much good may it do them! Kate Sterling came from him here, and then Mrs Wedgwood.

Kate came to bid me farewell— She will be Mrs Ross when we next meet,Kate Sterling m. Alexander Ross on 17 May. D V [Deo volente: God willing]— (There being as Venables remarked, “two D—’s)—The two Ds are God and the devil. She went off without a symptom of emotion—was that well? or ill?—at all rates it is well that if she have no “finer sensibilities”Coterie speech. she do not pretend to any.

Mrs George Rennie came to insist on our dining with them on the 7th May. Would send the Brougham for us—and it should take us after to our soirée at Bath House. In short it was dining made easy—and Mr C said finally, with inward curses, that “there was no refusing her” She looks very well, and was kind in her cold formal way. I had been fretting over the need of a new dress for the Bath House affair; but now I went after it with alacrity. George should see that the smart girl of his ProvenceThus in MS; presumably for “Province.” wasn’t become a dowdy among London women of “a certain age.“—
dined at Forsters. The two Mr Speddings there.James Spedding (1808–81; ODNB; see 28:38228:biographical note) and Thomas Story Spedding (;1800–1870; see 28:38228:biographical note). A slow dinner.
Walked a good spell today. Called at Bath House.

30th Walked to Alabasters and bought a bonnet. and took some things to be framed at Watsons—Alabaster and Toovey, 115 Piccadilly; Edward Watson, carver and guilder, 201 Piccadilly. dined at the Wedgwoods. such a large party; “distinguished females” “not a few”! Mrs GaskellElizabeth Cleghorn Gaskell, b. Stevenson (1810–65; ODNB; see 24:50–51JWC to JW, 17 May 1849, and 27:39627:biographical note), writer. said; “Mrs Carlyle! I am astonished to meet you here; Miss Jewsbury told me last week she thought you dying” “She was right”; I said, and there our discourse ended. “I do not like thee Dr Fell, The reason why &c &c“—“I do not like thee, Dr. Fell, / The reason why I cannot tell; / But this I know and know full well, / I do not like thee, Doctor Fell”; commonly found in collections of children’s nursery rhymes but ascribed to the satirist Tom Brown (1663–1704), referring to Dr. John Fell (1625–86), bishop of Oxford. What is that quality in the skins of some women, both in pictures and in real life which always suggests nakedness—striptness? Mrs G for instance reminds me always of a servant girl who has pulled of her gown to scrub her neck at the pump!

such a first of May for bitter cold! All day in the house, shivering. Lady Stanley and her MotherHenrietta Dillon, b. Browne (1789–1862), m., 1807, Henry Augustus Dillon-Lee (1777–1832; ODNB), 13th Viscount Dillon. came—and we engaged to go to Lady S’s party on Saturday night.— When I had sent off for Mrs Strachan to consult about new trimming my white silk gown; I reminded myself of the “Bairns” of the “wee wifie that lived in a shoe”

lg.l: “She went to the Butcher to buy a sheep’s head
When she came back they were all lying dead
She went to the Wright’s to order a coffin

When she came back they were all sitting laughing!”One of the many older versions of the nursery rhyme of the old woman who lived in a shoe; cf. “Old Mother Hubbard”; see The Oxford Dictionary of Nursery Rhymes (1951) 317–22, 434–35.
Last week I was all for dying; this week all for ball dresses!

div1.p:
15th May—Alack!—hiatus of a whole fortnight! for no particular reason; only a general indisposition to do anything today that could possibly be put
off till tomorrow. Perhaps it is a symptom of returning health this almighty indolence; or is it a premonitory symptom of apoplexy? I’m sure I don’t know; and sometimes don’t care.

Our dinner at the Rennies’ was like everything looked forward to with pleasure an entire failure! The Past stood aloof; looking mournfully down on me while the clatter of knives and forks, the babble of the guests, and the tramping of waiters confused my soul and senses. It was a London dinnerparty! voilà tout! [that’s all] And the recollection, which I could not rid myself of, that the gentlemanly “iron-grey” man who as Landlord offered me “roast duck” and other “delicacies of the season” had been my Lover,—my fiancé—once on a time—served only to make me shy, and in consequence stupid; And it was a relief when Ruskin called for us, to go to a great soirée at Bath House. There I found my tongue—and used it. “not wisely, but too well.”Othello 5. 2. There too I felt myself remarkably well dressed— At the Rennies I was always pulling my scarf up to my throat, with a painful consciousness of being over smart—

No other party since except a little early tea-party at Geraldines where I met, for the first time Mrs de Winton Authoress of Margaret & her Bridesmaids.Julia Cecilia De Winton, b. Collinson (1812–78), m., 1831, Walter Williams (later De Winton); Margaret and Her Bridesmaids, 3 vols. (1856). I have not for years seen a woman who so captivated me at first sight; or indeed at any number of sights. There is a charm of perfect naturalness about her that is irresistable. When she went out of the room I felt quite lost—like to cry!— I said to Geraldine when she returned from seeing her off “what an adorable woman!” Geraldine burst out laughing and said her (Mrs de Wintons) remark on me had been “I could adore that woman”!— I might well tell Mr Ross when he spoke of his first “remarkably disagreeable” impression of myself: “of course—these things, you know are always mutual”!
I must see her again; tho chi sa [who knows]? perhaps it were better not!

Thomas Erskine writes to me that poor Betty’s son is dying—her only son!George Braid (d. 1865; see 28:202JWC to BB, 13 July 1853). Another reason why I should make an effort to get to Scotland this Autumn—the sight of “her bairn” might comfort her a little

Mr KneightonWilliam Knighton. told us last night that when Sir Charles NapierProbably relating to Charles Napier’s command during the Second Sikh War, 1848–49 (rather than to his earlier tours of duty in India); the conflict had ended by the time he arrived; he resigned, 1850. was about going to India a person was dispatched to his house late one evening to tell him it was of the greatest importance he should start soon; “when did he think he could be ready” “Let me see” said Sir Charles taking out his watch,
“what time it is now—well— I can be ready in half an hour—will that do.” And he spoke in perfect good faith. The messenger smiled and told him he believed a fortnight hence was as soon as he was expected to go.
What a capital man!TC also admired him; see 8:10–11TC to JAC, 12 Jan. 1835, and vol. 31. it reminded me of my Father, who was just as prompt—nay would probably have said “in a quarter of an hour”!

Remarkable for being the day of my second Oratorio! Oh goodness me! how my sensibility to music must have diminished, or how my sense of “the fitness of things” must have increased, since my first Oratorio in Edinr Old Parliament House! Jeptha’s daughter in The Parliament HousePresumably Handel’s oratorio Jephtha (1751). Jephtha’s da. was Iphis. JWC may mean Parliament House, beside St. Giles’ Cathedral, Parliament Sq., Edinburgh, which housed the law courts (see 4:293TC to HI, 3 Dec. 1827), but, more probably, Parliament Hall, part of the same complex, where the Scottish parliament had met, 1639–1707, and where advocates and their clients met (for TC’s description; see Carlyle, Reminiscences 351–52). carried me away—away into the spheres! at the first crash of the chorus, I recollect a sensation, as of cold water poured down my back which grew into a positive physical cramp! The Messiah at Exeter House,The Royal Society of Music’s annual performance of Handel’s Messiah, Exeter Hall, 16 May. tho’ perfectly got up—“given,” they call it—left me calm and critical on my rather hard bench; and instead of imaginary cold water I felt stifled by the real heat—of the place! Geraldine said her sister (“the religious Miss Jewsbury“—Maria Jane Jewsbury (1800–1833), writer, who brought Geraldine up; after marriage, 1832, to W. K. Fletcher (d. 1867), a chaplain to the East India Co., she d. in Poona; see 12:297TC to GEJ, 21 Oct. 1840. in contradistinction from Geraldine)” wouldn’t let her go to the Messiah when a girl, because “people she thought, who really believed in their Saviour would not go to hear singing about him.” I am quite of the religious Miss Jewsbury’s mind. Singing about him with shakes, and white gloves and all that sort of thing, quite shocked my religious feelings; tho’ I have no religion. Geraldine did a good deal of emotional weeping at my side; and it was all I could do to keep myself from shaking her and saying “come out of that”! For my share, I was more in sympathy with the Piper’s cow!

lg.l: “The cow considered wi’ hersel
Music would ne’er fill her.
Gie me a lock of wheat strae
And sell ye’r wind for siller.”See 7:269TC to JAC, 15 Aug. 1834, and 10:89TC to LMC, 30 May 1838.

div1.p: Such a set of ugly creatures as the Chorus women I never did see! I grew so sorry for them, reflecting that each had a life of her own, that perhaps “somebody loved that pig”See 25:225TC to JWC, 19 Sept. 1850. that if I had had any tears in me at the moment, I should have cried for them all packed there like Herrings in a barrel into one mass of sound!

I am afraid it is a truth what Madame Malbére the Milliner,Of Henriette Malbère & Co., 35 S Audley St. said of me to Geraldine; “Vraiment, votre ami Madame Carlyle est trop defecile” [Truly your friend Mrs. Carlyle is too hard to please].

17th— Kate Sterlings Marriage-day—poor girl!— And it has thundered and it has hailed and it has pourd. My most interesting occupation reading Palmers Trial“Wife poisoner” (TC’s note on MS). William Palmer (1824–56; ODNB), the Rugeley poisoner. Palmer was accused of killing John Parsons Cook, a fellow gambler who died of violent stomach spasms after winning £800 at Shrewsbury races, Nov. 1855. A trained surgeon, Palmer was widely suspected of murdering at least sixteen people, including his wife and brother, but these latter charges were dropped for lack of evidence. The govt. was determined to convict him, and the Trial of Offences Act was passed, April 1856, allowing him to be tried for Cook’s death at the Central Criminal Court, at the Old Bailey, rather than a local court. The Annual Register … 1856 reported that the case, “which had excited such terrible interest in every fireside in England … necessarily drew vast crowds to the spot where the question of guilt or impunity was finally to be decided” (“Chronicle” [1857] 387). His conviction was gained by the rhetoric of the chief prosecutor, Alexander Cockburn (1802–80; ODNB); he was hanged, 14 June 1856. See also John Sutherland, Victorian Fiction: Writers, Publishers, Readers (1995) 35–42.
18th (Sunday)

Mrs de Winton came to lunch here by invitation. Mr C being to spend the day at Addiscombe I had taken the liberty of inviting her! Perhaps I shall go this summer to visit her at her Castle in Wales.Maesllwych, Hay, Radnorshire, on the Welsh borders. She has asked Geraldine and me, for a long visit. Geraldine came with her and staid all day. and we had Mr Munro,Possibly Alexander Munro (1825–71; ODNB), sculptor, living at 6 Upper Belgrave Pl. Mr Tait, Edward Stirling and George CookJohn George Cooke; later to become JWC’s close friend, she described him later as “a man betwixt thirty and forty,—tall, strong, silent, sincere,—has been a sailor, a soldier, a New Zealand settler, ‘a Man about Town,’ and a Stock Broker!!!” (JWC to Mary Russell, 10 Oct. 1864; MS: NLS 608.387; pbd: Bliss, JWC 319). here all at once. Now, there is not a sound in the house but the ticking of the clock— Anne out—and Mr C not to be home till tomorrow.

29th Day of the Celebration of the Peace—The celebration of the end of the Crimean War was marked by a national day off work. Nothing written then here since the 18th! And yet there has been “nothing very particular to prevent me.” Only general debility and despair! Only!

I went to Richmond one day—and caught a fresh cold which has made an inroad on the poor strength I had left—so that I have been, and still am little up to “distracting myself” with walking and visiting. Old Mrs DermotUnidentified. said to me the other day when I encountered her after 2 years— “Yes Mam my daughter is dead!— Only Child, House and everything gone from me! and I assure you I stand up in the world as if it wasn’t the world at all, any more, I understood that odd expression so well! Palmer is convicted after a horridly interesting Trial lasting twelve days. From first to last he has preserved the most wonderful coolness, forcing a certain admiration from one, Murderer tho’ he be! Mr Barlow says “nine tenths of the misery of human life proceeds, acording to his observation from The Institution of Marriage!” He should say from the demoralization—the desecration of the Institution of Marriage and then I should cordially agree with him.Froude omitted the discussion of Palmer but included these two sentences discussing marriage; after one final shortened entry from 27 June, he then printed extracts from Jewsbury’s letter about JWC’s misery in her marriage (seebelow, 263GEJ to JAF, 22 Nov. 1876, and LM 2:273). A. Carlyle noted on the typescript: “The context shows that Mrs C. in writing thus of marriage is referring to the case of Palmer, ‘the Wife-poisoner’ & not to her own marriage, as Froude’s citation of an isolated sentence or two, would lead one to believe. One can’t but admire (in the literal sense) Froude’s wonderful skill in misinformation. Certainly he had genius enough that way to ‘drive the Genii to despair.’ A.C.” See NLM 2:101 for his altered pbd. note. Colonel Sterling is returned for good—may he be happy with his friends and they with him! for me; I am no longer his friend. and, alas for him, neither am I his enemy— I am simply and honestly indifferent to him.

Went, well muffled up, in a cab to Bath House to see the fireworks,To celebrate the day of peace; in London fireworks displays were held in Hyde Park, Green Park, Victoria Park, and Primrose Hill: “The illuminations of the streets in the evening were general and brilliant, and … all the leading thoroughfares were literally packed with pedestrians and vehicles” (“Chronicle,” Annual Register … 1856 [1857] 116). and saw them as well as they could be seen. But of all spectacles fireworks are the most unsatisfactory to me—the uppermost feeling is always “what a waste”!—of money of time, of human ingenuity and labour and of—means of destruction! The spectacle while it lasts gratifies no sense but the eyesight—and then
it is so transitory—and there remains of it nothing! Francis Baring said every rocket that went up the only reflection he made to himself was; “there goes half-a crown!”—“In London the display was costly and effective” (Annals 462). Francis Baring (1800–1868), later Baron Ashburton, Lord Ashburton’s brother. Mr Carlyle compared the fireworks to “Parliamentary-eloquence.” The thing that pleased me most in the whole business was a clear broad light that from time to time spread over the street underneath and the swarm of people in it—and the neighbouring buildings—and the demon-like little figures moving about in the Park, kindling the fire works; it was a thing to paint if one had been a Cuyp.The name of a Dutch family that produced two generations of painters; JWC probably refers to Albert Cuyp (1620?–91), landscape painter known for his subtle and poetic use of light.
30th Too cold “for anything” Mrs George here in the forenoon—and Mrs Gaskell later— Dr Carlyle presented himself at tea time. A most useless tiresome day.

31st Countess Pepoli came at twelve “with a fly” and her sister’s footman to boot,She had three surviving sisters: Jessie Fergus (who lived with their brother John in Fife), Jane Royd, and Isabella Lumsden; footman unidentified. and invited me to a drive about the streets. I went and waited at various shopdoors while she did her shopping and took the opportunity,A page is cut out here; on his typescript, A. Carlyle has put “(Sic) xxx / xxx paper torn.”

[1 June. Sunday. Allingham “staid a long while telling“]Words in square brackets written by A. Carlyle at the top of the MS page, following the cut-out page. me all about himself. But that is a sort of thing I am getting used to, and which every woman must get used to, I suppose, when she has become elderly—decidedly. When I was young and charming; men asked me about myself, and listened with interest real or pretended to whatever I pleased to tell them—Now they compensate to themselves for the want of charm in my company by using me up as a listener to their egotism. A woman who will accept and exploit that rôle may still exercise an influence—of a sort. and if she cannot do without influence with men she had better accept it. For my part I think “the game isn’t worth the candle.”Proverbial; not worth the effort. At least that is my profound belief tonight after my dose of Mr Allingham’s early difficulties with an un-poetical Father and an ill-tempered Step mother,Allingham’s father was also William (1789–1866); his mother was Mary, b. Crawford (1790–1833); his stepmother, m. 1834 (when William was 10), was Isabella, b. Johnston (1800?–1895). and an unsympathizing public. The man
whom every body calls “George Cook”His first name was John. came as Allingham went, and he, to do him justice, talked very pleasantly on “things in general,“—but then, it was but his second visit, and he had still to make his place good. He staid two hours and a half! not busy, it would seem!About six lines are cut out here, presumably by TC.

6th“June, 1856” (TC’s note on MS). Lunched at Darwin’s—who drove me to call at Mrs Rennie’s and Lady Broke’s.“([D]on’t know her)—” (TC’s note on MS). A. Carlyle notes on typescript: “It was Lady de Capel Broke. Mrs Carlyle’s statement that one of her reasons for not visiting this Lady before (see ante p. 11 [see above, 31 Oct. 1855]) was Carlyle’s disapproval of her making new acquaintances on her ‘own basis,’ is scarcely credible. For she now makes the Lady’s acquaintance as much on her ‘own basis’ as she would have done before,—the only difference being that she is introduced by Darwin instead of Miss Jewsbury. Mrs C’s real reasons for refusal on the former occasion were evidently those she considered ‘interesting not to state’ [see above, 31 Oct. 1855]. It is unlikely that Carlyle’s permission was ever asked; it is more unlikely that he would have declined to grant it if he had been asked; and more unlikely still that he should have forgotten the lady’s name.”

18th Another break! on the 7th went to Addiscombe and stayed till the 11th. The place in full bloom and her Ladyship affable! Why? What is in the wind now? As usual at that beautiful place, I couldnt sleep.About six lines are cut out here.

Last Sunday George Rennie called. We talked about prayer (the “impertinence” of it according to George) about Palmer, finally “launched into Eternity,”Hanged. (as the phrase is), and about the prospects of War with America!John Fiennes Twisleton Crampton (1805–86; ODNB), diplomat, British minister to the U.S., 1852–56 (sec. to the legation, 1845–52); the U.S. broke off diplomatic relations, 28 May, because of anger at his recruitment of soldiers there for the Crimean War; this led to widespread rumors of war; Crampton arrived in Liverpool, 15 June, was knighted, 20 Sept., and continued his diplomatic career in Europe. Nice topics for dear friends meeting after a dozen years!

This morning 18th I got up with a dertmination [determination] to “make an effort,” at least; and achieved a short walk before breakfast—sorted about in drawers and presses. I am like the old Manchester womanUnidentified. who “could never kneel down comfortable to say her prayers, till she had swept the floor and whitened the hearth, and given herself a good wash.” The first thing with
me always, when I “take a notion” of living a more “purpose like” life, is to make a general “ridding up” of my drawers and presses &c!
Dined at the Pepolis’—a Mrs HughesUnidentified. and Mr Fergus the only company.

19th. Baked—with interruptions, first dear little diamond eyed Mrs Twisleton came to say goodbye—for this season. Then Mr Barlow. Both these said beautiful things to me—things equally flattering “to my head and hort,”Coterie speech; see 24:105JWC to TC, 7 July 1849. but no flatteries stick just now. It is as much as I can do to let alone answering like C’s Father, short and grim, “I don’t believe thee”!

Dined at old Mr Richardsons.Probably John Richardson; see 21:137TC to JAC, 17 Jan. 1847. A pleasant party as parties go. The Milmans. Aldersons Lord Minto, (eyes much too close) Dr Lushington;Henry Hart and Mary Anne Milman; the Aldersons are unidentified; possibly the hosts at “Dr. and Mrs. Alderson’s,” where Mrs. Brookfield mentioned dining in “rare dull company” (1849, Brookfield, Circle 2:279), and possibly James Alderson (1794–1882; ODNB), physician, and his wife; Gilbert Elliot (1782–1859; ODNB), 2d earl of Minto, politician; Dr. Lushington unidentified, possibly Stephen Rumbold Lushington (1776–1868; ODNB), hon. DCL Oxford, 1839, or Edmund Law Lushington (1811–93; ODNB; see 25:309TC to EF, 17 Dec. 1850), prof. of Greek, Glasgow Univ., 1838–75, Tennyson’s brother-in-law. According to a comment submitted to the CLO Feedback Page by Osmund Bullock on 24 Oct. 2010, JWC refers to Stephen Lushington (see below, n. 273), who was “invariably known as ‘Dr Lushington.’” and a good many intelligent looking men dropt in after dinner, besides Mary Stanley of Crimean notoriety (a very considerable of a goose I think)Mary Stanley (1814–79), da. of Edward Stanley (1779–1849), bishop of Norwich, and Lord Stanley’s cousin. She had been a close friend of Florence Nightingale, but in 1854, against Nightingale’s wishes, she went to the Crimea with a contingent of 15 Catholic nuns, 9 “ladies,” and 22 nurses. There was an immediate rift with Nightingale as Mary Stanley’s party was largely untrained and unprepared. A Roman Catholic convert (which she had kept secret in order to be allowed to go to the Crimea), Stanley was accused of spreading Roman Catholic propaganda in the Crimea and was sent home in March 1855. Later in 1855 she, with others, signed a formal complaint to the War Office against Nightingale. (See F. B. Smith, Florence Nightingale: Reputation and Power [1982] 43–47.) and a Miss Lushington, whom I asked, “Who is that old gentleman who talks in such pathetical tones, they called him Judge of the Ecclesiastical Court; but what is his name?” “Oh—that is my Father!”Stephen Lushington (1782–1873; ODNB), ecclesiastical judge; he had five das. According to a comment submitted to the CLO Feedback Page on 24 Oct. 2010 by Osmond Bullock, contemporary usage identifies the speaker as Lushington’s eldest unmarried da., at the time Frances Lushington (ca. 1827–1900).
Ah!

A thunder-showery day—did some trifle of needlework and finished Laportes Memoirs of his Valetship—Pierre de la Porte (1630–80), Mémoires de M. La Porte, premier valet de chambre de Louis XIV. Contenant plusieurs particularités des Règnes de Louis XIII & de Louis XIV (Geneva, 1755). Also in Claude Petitot, ed., Collection de mémoires relatifs à l’histoire de France (Paris, 1819–29). A short walk with Geraldine— A call
from Darwin— Oh— I had nearly forgotten the one bit of amiability I have done for weeks. I wrote a little complimentary letter to Miss Kelly or Kelty,Mary Ann Kelty (1789–1873; ODNB), Waters of Comfort: A Small Volume of Devotional Poetry (Cambridge, 1856); author of many works (many pbd. under M.A.K. and many devotional), incl. The Favourite of Nature (1820), Biography for Young Ladies (1839), Early Days in the Society of Friends (1840), and Fireside Philosophy (1842). She became an evangelical after her parents’ death, 1822; she moved from Cambridge to London, 1832, and lived for the rest of her life at 5 Hanover St., Rye Lane, Peckham, S London. Her working as a governess is unconfirmed. the unseen old Governess, who sends me from time to time a little book “all out of her own head.” Poor lonely old soul! this time she has burst out into poems! “Waters of Comfort” so-called! for the ‘Comfort’ it may be strongly doubted; tho’ nobody can deny the ‘Water’; but the fact of a lonely old exGoverness pouring herself out in Waters (even only meant to be) “of Comfort” at an age when most of us harden into flint, or crumble into dry dust, is of itself beautiful and touching! And I wrote to tell her this, as I know she is very sensible to sympathy

21st The contessa“Pepoli (once Elizth Fergus)” (TC’s note above the line). made me a very morning call, and a very kind one. She is a truehearted woman Elizabeth Pepoli, and I am wrong not to cultivate her more.

As she took her departure a message came that “Miss Jewsbury and the BishopCharles Hughes Terrot and Jewsbury were friends. He had written a long, affectionate letter to her, 29 Aug. 1855, (“There is no need to tell me I ‘was a man before I was a Bishop’”) in which he discussed marriage and divorce (“I go the length of preferring the Scotch system to the English, because it is fairer—it puts the husband & wife, rich & poor on a level whereas the English is only for the rich man”), love and the nature of truth. At the end, he says of JWC, “Tell her to think of me as favorably as she can. I can say through you anything that I ought to say to her—and I hope she will write to me, not as to a coward, but as one having been burned avoids the fire—at any rate if she knew all my present trial she would be sorry for me. / Any good news from Chelsea wd be a relief to me—& the mere expression of continued kindness is very acceptable” (MS: NLS 1767.83 where it is placed with an envelope addressed, probably by Jewsbury, to JWC at Addiscombe, PM: Croydon, 31 Aug.). were waiting for me.” Oh my Stars! how boring is this intrigue with nothing in it of anything that constitutes an intrigue but the mystery!—boring and ridiculous! If Mr C had let the poor old ugly man come here in peaceTC adds on MS: “alas, I didn’t hinder him to come; but he was (and still is) unbeautiful to me considerably, in body and mind! in paralysis or semi-paralysis now (1866), after remarrying (rich, rather questionable widow of 3 Husbands, &c), which sank him here, witht aid of mine.” His 2d wife, Charlotte Madden (d. 1862), m. 1859, is noted by the ODNB as a widow, but not of how many husbands. His first wife, Sarah Ingram (b. Wood) had d. 9 Sept. 1855. They had 14 children; their eldest da., Sarah Anne Terrot (1822–1902), a friend of Dickens, went to the Crimea with Nightingale and was decorated on her return; see also her Reminiscences of Scutari Hospitals in Winter 1854–55 (Edinburgh, 1898). I
might have sewed while he stayed, or otherwise enlivened our talk. Went all three for what the people here call a ride on the water in a steamboat. Landing at Paul’s Way“Wharf” (TC’s note above the line); a landing place on the Thames, S of St. Paul’s Cathedral. we were caught in the rain, and I returned by myself in the cabin of the next boat, prefering being stifled to being soaked—under the circumstances.
Dished for the rest of the day
22d (Sunday).

Saffi, George Rennie and his son, Geraldine George Cook and Edward Sterling in the forenoon; Dr Carlyle Mr Allingham, Tom Taylor and his wife and Geraldine (again) in the evening. If that isn’t society enough for one day!

Today is the first time I have felt natural with George Rennie the presence of Geraldine helped to give me possession of my present self. He looked at me once as if he were thinking I talked rather well. In the old times we never thought about how one another talked nor about how oneself talked! one had things to say and said them, just!

Did a little mending. Called at Bath House— “Ladyship “gone in the carriage to Addiscombe” Called at Grosvenor Street “Lady shipPresumably Lady Sandwich, now living at 46 Grosvenor Sq. gone in the carriage to Norwood”; came thro’ Wardour StreetBetween Oxford St. and Shaftesbury Ave. and flung away 18 shillings on a piece of nonsense!
